sen.e: Kinga INOUE (1732 - August 1, 1784) was a Japanese Confucianist who lived in the mid-Edo period.

sen.e: Kinga's real name was Tatemoto (or Tatsumoto or Tachimoto or Ryugen), and his azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was Junkei or Junkyo (which could be written either as "順卿" or "純卿" in Japanese), and his common name was Bunpei (or Fumihira or Fumihei).

sen.e: Kinga's ancestry can be traced back to a samurai family of Shinano Province, and one of his ancestors called Daizen, who was of nine generations ahead of Kinga, was a retainer of Nobunaga ODA and reportedly killed in battle at Honno-ji Temple.

sen.e: At the age of 24 Kinga abandoned his family profession of doctor of the Kasama Domain so as to become a Confucianist, and he first temporarily lived in Komagome where he gathered auditors and lectured in front of them.

sen.j: この際一人当たり30文を講義料として徴収しており、日に150人以上集ったということであるから銅銭4貫500文を得ていたことになり衣食住には充分な稼ぎだったようだ。
sen.e: When giving a lecture, Kinga charged 30 mon (unit of copper currency) per person (auditor), and as it is said that more than 150 persons per day listened to his lecture, Kinga accordingly earned about 4 kan 500 mon (the term kan is a unit of copper currency in Edo, the 4 kan equaling 4,000 mon equaling 1 ryo [unit of gold currency]) per day, which was sufficient for clothing, food and housing expenses.

sen.e: Giving a lecture for earning money (tuition fee) was called iku-ko (literally, rice porridge lecture), and after Kinga, everyone who opened a private school ('juku' in Japanese) at Komagome followed Kinga's way of making a living by providing the iku-ko (lectures for sale).

sen.e: Kinga got married at the age of 26, but his first wife died of illness about a year after the marriage, and he married for the second time a daughter of the Takei clan without delay.

sen.e: At the time Kinga published the "Joen-ki," his master Randai and Kinga alias Dojin KINGA co-authored some gesaku (light fiction, especially of the late Edo period) including "Toshisho" (literally, making fun of Chinese poems, which was a parody of "Toshisen" [Selection of Tang Poems, late 16th century]) and "Shosetsu Hakuto-den" (literally, novelization of the legend of white wisteria, which was written in slangy Chinese and portrayed some characters resembling famous contemporaries such as Sorai OGYU).

sen.e: At the age of 34 Kinga was given by a medical scholar Rankei TAKI, who had heard people speak highly of Kinga, a free hand to administer a private medical school Seijukan, where he also gave lectures himself.

sen.e: More specifically, Kinga had maintained close relations with Genba YOSHIDA, who was a Karo (senior retainer) of Obata Domain of Kozuke Province, and this Genba YOSHIDA fell victim to slander and was imprisoned together with Ryuso YAMAGATA, who was a political advisor to the Lord on the domain duties, on suspicion of treachery.

sen.j: 天明4年（1784年）、公澄法親王に随行し日光山に登ったが、背中に疽（悪性の腫れ物）が出来て、急遽、駕籠にて下山。
sen.e: In 1784, as Kinga accompanied Cloistered Imperial Prince Kocho climbing up Nikko-san mountains, he suffered from a kind of carbuncle (an extensive skin eruption which is similar to but larger than a boil and has several openings through which pus is discharged, being caused by staphylococcal infection) which had emerged on the back, thereby being sent back by kago (Japanese palanquin) in haste.
sen.cmt: 原文に西暦年および「山」を補足の上訳出しました。また、「駕籠」（乗り物）の「駕」の字が抜けていましたので補足しました。注：wikiサイト上では「籠」（入れ物）のままです。また、同サイト上では公澄法親王のことを「東叡（大）王」という尊称にしてありました。疽（癰[よう] carbuncle, の一種とのこと) [1] http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=%E7%96%BD&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=12407310683300 [2] http://www.google.co.jp/search?sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&q=%E7%99%B0
sen.e: In 1784, as Kinga accompanied Cloistered Imperial Prince Kocho in climbing Mt. Nikko, he suffered from a kind of carbuncle which emerged on his back, thereby descended the mountain in haste, being carried on kago (Japanese palanquin).

sen.e: Since Kinga's house was under construction at that time, he stayed and was undergoing medical treatment at Rankei TAKI's house, but died of illness in August.

sen.e: Bearing comparison with Koyo NAKAYAMA's paintings and Toko SAWADA's calligraphy, both of whom Kinga had associated with, Kinga's Gasan (inscriptions associated with paintings) enjoyed high popularity among prominent figures of Edo.

sen.j: 金峨は師 熊峯から古義学を、師 蘭台から朱子学と古文辞学を修め、折衷学を確立した。
sen.e: Kinga studied Kogigaku (study of pursuing ancient meanings of Confucius and Mencius based on their original texts, by Jinsai ITO's Ancient Meaning school) under Yuho and Shushigaku (Neo-Confucianism) and Kobunjigaku (the study of archaic words and phrases) under Randai, thus establishing a school of Secchugaku (eclecticism).

sen.j: 当時一世を風靡していた古文辞学（徂徠学）の誤りを理論的に指摘した『弁徴録』を刊行すると一躍、学会の注目を受けることとなる。
sen.e: The predominant thinking of the day was the Kobunjigaku (Sorai-gaku), but Kinga in his "Benchoroku" pointed out errors in the Kobunjigaku theoretically, thereby entering the limelight in the academic society.

sen.j: 折衷学とは榊原篁洲を祖として端を発した学問であり、各学派間の争いを反省して起こった。

sen.j: 諸説の優れた点を吸収しひとつの派閥に偏らないことが特徴である。
sen.e: The Secchugaku is characterized by adopting good points of various theories and being balanced.
The Secchugaku is characterized by adopting good points of various theories and being balanced among them.

sen.j: 金峨は、朱子、王陽明、伊藤仁斎、荻生徂徠の四家から優れたところを抽出し、自らの折衷学に取り入れている。
sen.e: Kinga extracted only the good points from the thoughts of the four major Confucianists who were Chu His, Yomei O (Wang Yangming), Jinsai ITO and Sorai OGYU, so as to incorporate them into his own Secchugaku (eclecticism).

sen.j: 漢詩に関しては当時流行していた唐詩を形骸化していると批判し、後の宋詩流行の先駆となった。
sen.e: On the prevailing Chinese poetry, Kinga criticized its loss of substance and pioneered the future trend of Song Dynasty style poetry in Japan.

sen.j: また門弟の亀田鵬斎、山本北山、吉田篁墩らの門下に多くの俊英が育ち、折衷学派は藩校を中心に全国に広まり明治期まで続いた。
sen.e: Further, Kinga's disciples Hosai KAMEDA, Hokuzan YAMAMOTO and Koton YOSHIDA educated many brilliant minds, respectively, thus allowing the eclectic school (Secchugaku-ha) to keep spreading nationwide from around han-ko schools (schools of the feudal domains) until the Meiji period.
